title-group.article-title: Patient journey and timeliness of care for patients with breast cancer in Africa: a scoping review

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Timely access to breast cancer care is critical for improving prognosis and survival, but multiple barriers can lead to prolonged intervals across the care pathway. This scoping review aims to identify the methods used to measure timeliness in breast cancer care, pinpoint specific points in the care pathway where longer time intervals are most common and categorise the factors influencing the timeliness of care in Africa.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Scoping review followed the methodological framework for scoping reviews outlined by Arksey and O’Malley.

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: Five electronic databases, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, Web of science, and PsycINFO, were searched for articles published between 1999 and 2024, and the Google search engine was used to search for grey literature.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria for selecting studies
sec.p: We included studies that measured time to presentation, diagnosis or treatment within the context of breast cancer care in Africa, and/or assessed one or more of these care intervals.

sec.title: Data extraction and synthesis
sec.p: Two reviewers independently screened relevant abstracts and full texts against the selection criteria. Key themes were then synthesised narratively based on a predefined theoretical framework adapted from the Model of Pathways to Treatment and Andersen’s model of health service.

sec.title: Result
sec.p: The initial search identified 3552 articles, with 29 studies ultimately included for data charting. All the included studies drew samples from healthcare facilities. This review identified seven multidirectional key time points: symptom onset, recognising the need for help, engaging with informal care providers, presenting at a health facility, receiving a diagnosis, consulting a specialist and starting treatment. The review also revealed significant variation in the terminology used for time events and in the metrics defining time intervals. The time interval between symptom recognition and contact with a healthcare provider was the most frequently studied and was often longer than other intervals. In many African countries, traditional healers and spiritual sites were the first point of contact for many patients with breast cancer after noticing initial symptoms. There was a scarcity of research into completion of cancer treatment and follow-up, despite significant barriers in accessing and affording cancer care.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This review highlights significant variation in how timeliness of breast cancer care are defined and measured across African countries, underscoring the need for standardised tools to assess care intervals. The predominance of facility-based studies may overlook patients who never reach formal healthcare settings, pointing to a critical gap in community-level evidence. These findings emphasise the importance of adopting a systems-based approach to improve breast cancer care, one that integrates both formal and informal care pathways and actively involves patients in navigating timely access to services.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: A comprehensive search was conducted, covering both peer-reviewed and relevant grey literature.

This review used the Model of Pathways to Treatment to map time events and Andersen’s model of health service utilisation to categorise factors associated with longer time intervals in breast cancer care.
This study was guided by a previously published protocol.
Quality of the included studies was not assessed.
Only studies published in the English language were included.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths among female patients, which disproportionately affects women in developing countries.1 In 2022, approximately 2.3 million people were diagnosed with breast cancer, accounting for 11.6% of all global cancer cases, and 665 683 individuals died from the disease, representing 6.9% of all cancer-related deaths worldwide.2 Developing regions, such as South America, Africa and Asia, have seen a rapid rise in both breast cancer incidence and mortality. For instance, the Global Cancer Observatory (GLOBOCAN) reported that in 2022, Africa recorded 1 98 342 cases and 91 173 deaths related to breast cancer. By contrast, Europe and North America had higher incidence rates but significantly lower mortality. For instance, Europe reported approximately 557 873 new cases and 144 510 deaths, while North America reported 3 06 198 cases and 49 727 deaths.3

In Africa, healthcare systems face a double burden of disease, grappling with high rates of infectious diseases and maternal and child mortality, alongside a disproportionately high increase in non-communicable diseases. The prevalence of breast cancer in Africa is expected to rise as more women adopt Western reproductive and dietary habits, which have been linked to an increased risk of the disease.4 Currently, breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in Africa, with its incidence steadily rising over the past 30 years. Mortality rates remain high, and survival rates are lower across the African continent as compared with developed countries.5 This is largely due to late-stage presentation and inadequate treatment.6 According to Duggan et al,7 studies from sub-Saharan African countries such as Ethiopia, Nigeria, Kenya and Ghana consistently report that fewer than 30% of invasive breast cancers are diagnosed at early stages (I or II), with the majority presenting at advanced stages (III or IV). In contrast, high-income countries consistently report early-stage diagnosis in more than 60% of invasive breast cancer cases. Achieving this level of early detection has been a common feature across countries with declining mortality rates, making it a clinically meaningful and reasonable goal for health systems in Africa.

Delayed presentation to health facilities after recognition of first symptoms largely contributes to advanced stage diagnosis of breast cancer.8 In Africa, more than half (54%) of African women with breast cancer delay seeking medical care for over 3 months after symptom recognition.9 Effective cancer care relies on key components such as early diagnosis, appropriate referral and access to evidence-based treatments, such as surgery, radiotherapy and systemic therapies. Early detection greatly improves treatment outcomes; however, in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), many cancer cases go unreported and many are diagnosed at advanced stages when the disease has become aggressive or has metastasised.10 11

The patient journey from the onset of symptoms to the completion of treatment is complex, with multiple stages that can differ greatly across various healthcare systems.12 Longer time intervals in presentation, diagnosis and treatment are major factors affecting breast cancer survival, yet they have not been comprehensively studied in Africa. The Breast Health Global Initiative has emphasised the need for downstaging interventions to promote early diagnosis and timely access to treatment in LMICs.13 Building on this, the WHO launched the Global Breast Cancer Initiative (GBCI) in 2021, which outlines a three-pillar framework for improving breast cancer outcomes globally: early detection, timely diagnosis and treatment to completion. The GBCI also introduces key performance indicators, including the recommendation that diagnosis be achieved within 60 days of symptom recognition.14 These benchmarks are intended to support standardisation and guide national cancer control programmes. Understanding the factors influencing time intervals in breast cancer care in Africa is essential to inform such efforts and develop strategies to promote earlier diagnosis and timely treatment initiation.15 Promoting early cancer diagnosis and timely access to treatment is a critical component of any comprehensive cancer control strategy. For example, patients with breast cancer who delay treatment by more than 3 months after symptom onset have a 12% higher 5-year mortality rate compared with those treated within 3 months.16 A recent systematic review and meta-analysis of 34 studies further revealed that a cancer treatment delay of just 4 weeks is associated with an increased risk of death.17

Adding to the complexity is the challenge of completing cancer treatment in resource-poor health systems, such as those in Africa. In Africa, longer time intervals in the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer are often influenced by systemic challenges within the healthcare system.18 Socioeconomic barriers, such as poverty and limited awareness, hinder timely access to care.19 The absence of universal health coverage exacerbates disparities, leaving many patients unable to afford or access essential medical services. Additionally, a shortage of healthcare workers and infrastructure further limits the capacity to provide timely and effective care. The coexistence of formal and informal care systems, with many patients consulting traditional healers or religious groups before or alongside formal healthcare, adds complexity.20 Furthermore, the lack of integration or referral pathways between these systems contributes to delays, preventing patients from receiving timely diagnosis and treatment.

Understanding the entire patient journey of cancer care is critical for creating interventions that promote timely detection. The measurement of time interval in breast cancer care is a key indicator for enhancing strategies aimed at improving the quality of care and service delivery, as well as for developing programmes that drive change. However, studies in Africa use various metrics to measure and define different time intervals in breast cancer care, with no common standardised cut-off point.21 22 Therefore, this scoping review aims to evaluate the methods used to measure the timeliness of breast cancer care, identify specific points in the care pathway where longer time intervals are most frequently reported and examine the factors affecting the timeliness of breast cancer care in Africa. It aims to provide a well-organised summary of findings to inform decision-making for policymakers, cancer programme managers and healthcare providers.

sec.title: Conceptual framework
sec.p: This scoping review used the Model of Pathways to Treatment to map time events, which specifies the essential events, processes and time intervals that may occur in the period prior to diagnosis and the completion of medical treatment.23 The Andersen’s model of health service utilisation was used to identify associated factors of timeliness of breast cancer care that may influence each interval.24 New themes were also added when they did not fit into the existing frameworks.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: The design of this study was guided by Arksey and O'Malley’s scoping review methodology,25 as enhanced by Levac and colleagues and the Joanna Briggs Institute.26 27 The enhanced framework consists of five stages for conducting a scoping review: (1) formulating the research question, (2) determining relevant studies by defining inclusion and exclusion criteria, (3) searching for and selecting evidence, (4) charting the evidence and (5) collating, summarising and reporting the findings. The review adhered to the guidelines set forth by the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews. Detailed information about the study design has been published separately and no adjustment was made to the published protocol.28

sec.title: Data sources
sec.p: The literature search was guided by the review objectives and the population, concept and content (PCC) criteria.27 The search strategy was developed with guidance from a health sciences subject librarian and applied in accordance with the Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies guidelines. The search strategy was pretested prior to the actual search. Search terms and free-text words were combined using the Boolean operators ‘AND’ and ‘OR’ (full search strategy in online supplemental table 1).

A comprehensive literature search was conducted on the following electronic databases: MEDLINE, SCOPUS, CINAHL, Web of science, EMBASE and PsycINFO. Additionally, relevant grey literature sources were searched by using Google search engine for potentially eligible articles, such as the publication database of the WHO’s International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and the Cancer Atlas of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC). A hand-search of reference lists of included studies was conducted. All articles published up to the lastdate of search (20 June 2024) were considered, and only articles written in English were eligible.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria
sec.p: Inclusion criteria were defined using the PCC framework proposed by Peters and colleagues.27 The eligible population included women with breast cancer in African contexts. The concepts of interest were different time events of breast cancer care. To be eligible for inclusion, studies needed to have measured either the time to presentation, time to diagnosis or time to treatment within the context of breast cancer care in Africa, and/or assessed one of the time intervals, regardless of whether they evaluated factors associated with these time intervals.

Articles that focused solely or primarily on men and articles published in languages other than English were excluded. Studies that focused primarily on screening asymptomatic individuals were also excluded.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: The review process involved two levels of screening. After removing duplicate records, two reviewers (AAK and HY) independently screened the titles and abstracts of all retrieved articles using Covidence. Any articles considered relevant by either reviewer were included for full-text assessment. In the second step, the reviewers retrieved the full texts of those studies and independently evaluated them to determine whether they met the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Disagreements in eligibility assessment were resolved through discussions between the two reviewers or further discussions with the senior authors. A Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews flow diagram (figure 1) is presented to provide a comprehensive visual representation of the studies that were included and excluded during the process.

caption.title: Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses flowchart of the study selection process.

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: The data were extracted by the lead author AAK using a data chart form and examined by authors (CL, HJ and HY). The extracted data encompassed three domains: (1) study characteristics (authors, country of the study, publication year, study design, study setting, study population and sample size), (2) time events and time intervals (definition of time intervals and guidelines, time interval indicators, metrics to measure time intervals or timeliness and findings) and (3) factors associated with time intervals (predisposing, needs, enabling and contextual factors).24 Study eligibility was reverified at the start of/during data extraction.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: In this scoping review, data analysis involved both quantitative and qualitative synthesis. Frequency distributions of the included studies in terms of their characteristics and key findings were calculated.

The extracted data were coded to highlight important themes in line with the existing frameworks. Time to presentation, diagnosis and treatment were analysed according to the Model of Pathways to Treatment.23 Andersen’s model of health service utilisation was used to assess factors related to the patient, healthcare providers (HCP), the health system and the disease itself that could impact the timeliness of breast cancer diagnosis.24 Relationships between themes, populations and findings were illustrated using tables.
The quantitative and qualitative syntheses were summarised narratively to provide a clear and coherent presentation of the findings.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients or the public were not involved in this research.

sec.title: Search results
sec.p: A total of 3552 records were identified from literature database searches: SCOPUS (n=1067), MEDLINE (n=834), Embase (n=652), Web of science (n=437), CINAHL (n=423) and PsycINFO (n=139). After removal of the duplicates (n=1714), 1838 records went through screening by titles and abstracts: 1650 were deemed ineligible. The full texts of the remaining 188 potentially eligible studies were reviewed against the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. This resulted in a final sample of 29 studies included in the scoping review (figure 1).

sec.title: Characteristics of included studies
sec.p: Table 1 describes the characteristics of included studies. The studies were published from 1999 to 2024, with the vast majority (93.1%) published after 2011. The representation of studies across African regions was uneven. East Africa accounted for the largest number of studies (11), followed by West Africa (8) and Northern Africa (7), while Southern Africa had only two studies. Additionally, one multicentre study was conducted across Nigeria, Namibia, Uganda and Zambia. Almost 90% of the studies used a cross-sectional study design to investigate delays in different time intervals (patient, diagnostic and treatment time intervals).

tr.td: Multi-country: Nigeria, Namibia, Uganda and Zambia

sec.p: The study participants were mostly adult women who were diagnosed with breast cancer at any stage, though one Moroccan study29 restricted participants to patients with advanced breast cancer. All studies recruited study participants from cancer care facilities. Of these, 20 (69%) used samples drawn from a single institution, while nine used samples from multiple institutions, with sample size that individual studies used ranging from 14 to 1429. No studies drew samples from the community.

Most of (24/29) articles were quantitative and one used mixed method. More than 90% of studies collected data through structured or semistructured questionnaires, typically administered by trained researchers or medical staff around the time of diagnosis, with some data extracted from medical records. However, two studies relied solely on medical records retrospectively.30 31

sec.title: Time points in breast cancer care
sec.p: The selected articles identify several key time points related to breast cancer, including the onset of symptoms, recognition of the need to seek help, contact with informal care providers, presentation at a health facility, diagnosis, consultation with a specialist and the start of treatment. Table 2 depicts the full time point definitions.

caption.title: Definitions of key time points in the breast cancer care pathway

tr.td: Date of detection of bodily changes
The first date of recognition of the first symptom
Date patient perceived need to discuss with HCP
Visited traditional healer or religious leader
Start of surgery, chemo, hormone therapy, or radiotherapy

sec.title: Methods/tools used to define and for assessing time intervals of breast cancer care
sec.p: The studies showed considerable variation in the use of terminologies related to time events and intervals. For example, one study separated the appraisal interval (the time between symptom detection and the recognition of the need to seek help) from the help-seeking interval (the time between symptom detection and the first consultation with a HCP).32 Another study defined the appraisal interval as from the detection of the first symptom to its initial disclosure to family/community members (none HCP).33 However, most studies combined the appraisal and help-seeking intervals into a single interval (the time between symptom detection and the first HCP visit/consultation). While this combined interval was often labelled as ‘patient delay’,293134 other terms were also used: help-seeking interval,40 patient (-related) interval,41 42 precontact time,43 consultation time,44 time to first healthcare visit,45 time to presentation and delayed presentation.22 Besides, there were marked differences in how the intervals were named. For example, health-seeking interval33 46 and patient interval41 express the same time interval (time between symptom detection and first contact with healthcare provider). However, two studies defined health seeking interval as time between perceiving reasons to seek help and presentation to the first HCP.32 47

Similarly, different terminologies were used across studies to refer to the time between the first HCP visit and the date of diagnosis. Most studies used diagnostic interval,32 41 42 46 diagnostic delay31 35 38 or health system/provider delay.34 36 Other terms included time to diagnosis,45 diagnostic time,33 48 primary care interval and postcontact interval.43 The diagnostic interval was defined in various ways across studies: most commonly, it was defined as the time between the first HCP visit and diagnosis or from the presentation at a health facility to diagnosis.29 35 36 38 42 45 Terms like diagnostic delay and health system delay are often used interchangeably to refer to the time between the first HCP contact and diagnosis.38 45 However, two studies define health system delay as the interval between first contact with HCP to initiation of treatment29 34 and one study between the date of histological diagnosis and initiation of treatment.35

The time intervals from diagnosis to initiation of treatment were also named differently across studies, with terms such as pre-treatment interval,41 time to treatment,45 treatment delay,31 time to initial intervention,49 health system delay35 and delayed treatment.50

The included studies had limitations with unclear definitions of time intervals or timeliness and inconsistent methods for determining the lengths of these time intervals. Ten (34.5%) studies relied on the authors’ definitions of time intervals,3538 45 4851 31.0% of the studies (n=9)293136 37 52 53 adopted definitions from prvious studies.5463 Four (13.7%) studies used the Model of Pathways to Treatment, which focuses on events of patient journey from recognising symptoms to accessing healthcare and beginning treatment.32 41 46 47 Five (17.2%) followed the Aarhus Statement: focusing on identifying intervals between symptom recognition, healthcare contact, diagnosis and treatment initiation22 33 40 42 and one (3.4%) study adopted the five stages (appraisal, illness, behavioural, schedulingand treatment) from the Andersen Model.39

The cut-off points or metrics used to define prolonged time intervals varied significantly across studies. This variation is largely due to the lack of standardised guidelines or policy statements that establish a common benchmark for measuring the length of time intervals at each stage of breast cancer care. For example, the majority considered longer time intervals between time from symptom recognition and contact with the first HCP when the interval between the recognition of symptoms and the initial medical consultation exceeded 3 months. Notably, nearly half of the studies classified longer time intervals as 3 months or more,293134 37 while others set the delay at longer than 6 months,36 49 1 month35 or 1 week.29

Similarly, the interval between first contact with HCP to diagnosis was considered a longer time interval if it exceeded 1 month in four studies,33 34 42 65 while other studies used cut-off points of 16 days,35 2 months,38 3 months29 31 or 6 months.36

Moreover, the interval between diagnosis to the start of treatment was also evaluated. One study considered a long time interval if this interval exceeded 48 days35 while another defined it as more than 1 month.50 Other studies classified the duration from symptom detection to treatment initiation as a long-time interval if it was 3 months or longer53 (online supplemental table 2).

sec.title: Breast cancer care intervals
sec.p: 22 studies (75.9%) reported on the interval from symptom recognition to the first HCP visit. Fourteen studies (48.3%) examined the interval from first HCP contact to diagnosis, four studies (13.8%) assessed the time from symptom recognition to diagnosis, six studies (20.7%) investigated the interval from diagnosis to treatment initiation and two studies (6.9%) reported on the full interval from symptom detection to treatment initiation (figure 2). The interval ‘diagnosis to specialist consultation’ was rarely studied. The time from initial symptom recognition to first contact with HCP was commonly studied in breast cancer research in Africa because it often represented one of the longest and most impactful delays in the care pathway.66 Only one study assessed appraisal interval (between the recognition of breast symptoms to first disclosure, eg, to partners, family and friends) and help-seeking interval (between symptom recognition and first HCP visit) as separate intervals.33

caption.title: Time intervals and median durations in the breast cancer care pathway in Africa.

sec.title: Symptom recognition to contact with first HCP
sec.p: Overall, the time from symptom recognition to contact with first HCP varied widely across the African continent and even within individual countries. North African studies generally reported a shorter time interval with median estimates ranging from 1 week to 24 weeks in Morocco,29 35 4 weeks in Tunisia34 and 5 weeks in Egypt.65

In sub-Saharan Africa, this time interval was generally longer, ranging from 1 week among non-Black groups in Namibia to 52 weeks in Uganda. Median estimates of this time interval included 3–4 weeks in South Africa, Zambia and Ethiopia, 5 weeks among Namibia’s Black population,43 13–16 weeks in Kenya, Uganda, Libya, Nigeria and Ethiopia,22 43 48 49 and 19 weeks in Mali and Rwanda.36 45 Uganda and Ghana reported the longest time interval, at 48–52 weeks.30 37 67 This variation might be due to differences in healthcare infrastructure, socioeconomic conditions, cultural attitudes and public health systems. North African countries, such as Morocco and Egypt, often have a more mature healthcare system and better access to medical facilities than many sub-Saharan African countries.18
Ethiopia, Uganda and Morocco showed significant variability in this interval, highlighting heterogeneity within individual countries.

sec.title: Contact with first HCP to diagnosis
sec.p: Nearly half of the studies reported the time interval from contact with the first HCP to diagnosis. In North Africa, this interval was relatively shorter, with median estimates ranging from 1 week in Egypt to 17 weeks in Tunisia,29 31 34 65 while Sub-Saharan Africa reported longer duration in this time interval, with median estimates ranging from 3 weeks in Mali to 20 weeks in Rwanda.32 36 42 46 South Africa (4–13 weeks) and Morocco (2–14 weeks) showed notable variability in this interval, highlighting heterogeneity within each country.

sec.title: Symptom recognition to diagnosis
sec.p: Only a few studies assessed the time interval from symptom recognition to diagnosis. The median interval ranged from 30 weeks in Libya,48 34 weeks in Nigeria33 and 36 weeks in South Africa,32 to 60 weeks in Rwanda.36 One multicounty study reported this time interval for Namibia (10 weeks in non-Black women and 26 weeks in Black women), Nigeria (22 weeks), Uganda (45 weeks) and Zambia (33 weeks).43

sec.title: Diagnosis to initiation of treatment
sec.p: The median interval from diagnosis to initiation of treatment ranged from 5 weeks in South Africa and Mali,41 45 6 weeks in Morocco and Kenya31 49 and 7 weeks in Morocco,35 to 12 weeks in Ethiopia.53 The time interval from symptom recognition to treatment was reported as 16 weeks in South Africa and 36 weeks in Nigeria41 50 (table 3).

caption.title: Median time intervals from symptom recognition to presentation, diagnosis and treatment reported in the studies from Africa

tr.td: Symptom recognition to First HCP contact

fn.p: HCP, healthcare providers; N/R, not reported.

sec.title: Where patient go after symptom recognition?
sec.p: More than 90% of the included studies reported that breast lump was reported as the initial breast cancer symptom, and disclosure to family often triggered the patient to seek healthcare in most studies. In 37.5% of the studies, 27% to 90.7% of patients with breast cancer underestimated the seriousness of their symptoms.22 41 48 This was often due to limited knowledge about breast cancer symptoms and risks, limited healthcare access and cultural beliefs, and fear of stigma, which may prevent women from acknowledging or reporting breast abnormalities earlier.

In Africa, the path a patient took after detecting breast cancer symptoms varied significantly based on their specific circumstances, including their location, available resources and personal decisions. Patients with breast cancer in African countries tended to seek different first points of contact after detecting their initial symptoms, with traditional healers and spiritual places being the most common, particularly in Ethiopia (77.1%, 52.7%, 33.3%),22 40 52 Uganda (50%),37 Nigeria (50%, 45%)38 50 and Mali (35%, 24.2%).45 46 The next most common contact was tertiary hospitals, as seen in Rwanda (76%),36 Mali (50%, 45%),45 46 Ethiopia 23.3%42 and in the multicentre study across Namibia, Nigeria, Uganda and Zambia (61.6%).43 Following this, district hospitals were a frequent first choice, especially in South Africa (72%),41 Nigeria (75%)33 and Egypt (42%).65

Private clinics and community health centres were also the first point of contact, although private clinics were commonly used, especially in South Africa (22%),41 Egypt (35.4%)65 and Ethiopia (40.5%).42 Community health centres were also used in Ethiopia (54.4%, 36%)22 42 and Mali (20%).45

The breast cancer care journey in Africa was complex and marked by long-time intervals, non-linear progression, and sociocultural and economic challenges (figure 3). After cancer diagnosis, which typically occurred at higher-level hospitals due to limited diagnostic facilities in lower-level centres, poorly structured follow-up care and limited access to primary healthcare services led many to bypass community centres for tertiary hospitals. Financial barriers, fear and cultural beliefs delayed or disrupted treatment, with many patients returning to self-care or informal care providers. One study in Ethiopia showed that 34% of breast cancer patients visited a traditional healer between diagnosis and treatment initiation.53

caption.title: Breast cancer care pathway in Africa. FNAC, fine needle aspiration cytology; GP, general practitioner.

sec.title: Factors studied related to timeliness of breast cancer care in Africa
sec.p: Factors related to timeliness of breast cancer care were identified based on the Andersen's model of health service utilisation. This framework categorises predictors into predisposing, enabling, need and contextual factors to provide a clearer understanding of the barriers influencing patient, diagnostic and treatment time interval in healthcare utilisation.

sec.title: Factors influencing the time interval between symptom recognition and first HCP contact
sec.p: Almost all studies examined age and educational status as an independent variable and only 10 (34.4%) investigated residence as a predictor of longer duration in this time interval. Age was the most investigated predictor of longer duration in this interval, but only three studies from South Africa, Ethiopia and Nigeria identified it as statistically significant. Low educational status and rural residence were also significant predictors in a few studies. About 41% of the studies investigated contact with traditional healers as a predictor, and three studies linked visits to traditional healers to longer durations in this interval. Knowledge and practice of breast self-examination were evaluated in 32% of the studies, with four showing an association with prolonged duration in this time interval. Factors such as long travel distances, financial constraints and clinical factors, such as painless symptoms or misperceived symptoms, were also associated with longer duration in this time interval. Family history of breast cancer was less frequently significant, despite being examined in half of the studies.

sec.title: Factors associated with the time interval between first HCP contact and diagnosis
sec.p: Age and education were examined by 90% of the studies, with most reporting them as significant predictors, while occupation was examined in over half of the studies. One quarter of the studies examined failure to perform breast self-examination and two studies linked it to longer duration in this time interval. Other factors, including the type of HCP first seen, multiple facility visits, travel time and distance to health facilities, and the type of first consultation, were also associated with this time interval. A few studies highlighted the absence of a palpable lump and fear of diagnosis as predictors of longer duration in this time interval.

sec.title: Factors contributing to the time interval between diagnosis and treatment initiation
sec.p: Age, cancer stage, financial constraints and histological nodal status were associated with this time interval (table 4).

caption.title: Factors contributing to time intervals in breast cancer care in Africa.

tr.td: Symptom recognition to first HCP contact
Older age linked to longer time intervals (up to 4.8 x)22
Low education linked to 3.8–13 x longer intervals
Traditional healer visits before formal HCP36 42 84
2.13–4.2 x longer; avoiding reduces risk by 85%
Painless or no armpit lump=3.3–9 x longer; Recognising symptoms as cancer reduces delay (AOR=0.2)22 52
Fear of mastectomy, denial, misconceptions linked to delays
No family history of breast cancer=2.4–5.1 x longer52 84
Poor knowledge/practice linked to longer delays34 39 45 64
Older age increases intervals by 1.7 x
Being married=1.66 x higher risk of delay
Older age linked to longer intervals
Fibrocystic disease history linked to longer intervals29 48
Longer intervals in those without family history
Long distance from care increased delays
Older patients had 3.18 x higher odds of timely treatment53
Advanced stage=higher odds of timely care but also 1.78 x risk of delay41 43 51
Nodal involvement associated with treatment delays31

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the first scoping review to report on the metrics and definitions of various time intervals used to measure the breast cancer patient journey and related factors studied in African countries. The review identified seven key time points commonly studied, including symptom onset, recognising the need for help, engaging with informal care providers, presenting at a health facility, receiving a diagnosis, consulting a specialist,and starting treatment. Overall, breast cancer patients in Africa experienced a long care journey despite variations in median time intervals both between and within individual countries.

The time intervals from symptom recognition to first HCP contact, from first HCP contact to diagnosis and from diagnosis to treatment were generally longer than those reported in most studies from non-African countries.6870 Most studies included in this scoping review, with few exceptions, reported a median interval of 1–52 weeks between symptom recognition and first HCP contact, 1–20 weeks from HCP contact to diagnosis, 30–60 weeks between symptom detection and diagnosis and 5–12 weeks between diagnosis and initiation of treatment. They are significantly longer than those found in some developed countries such as the United Kingdom,71 the United States,70 France69 and Germany.72 However, they are comparable to estimates observed in some other LMICs, including Brazil,73 Colombia,74 Mexico and Malaysia.75 76

The time interval from symptom recognition to contact with a first HCP was studied more frequently, and this interval, along with the time from symptom detection to diagnosis, was longer compared with other time intervals. This finding is consistent with the two reviews on breast cancer diagnosis in LMICs.15 Previous reviews also identified the long time interval between symptom recognition and the first presentation to a HCP as a major cause for longer time intervals in breast cancer care.15 77 It suggests that delays often occur in the early stages of recognising and addressing breast cancer symptoms, which might reflect challenges like symptom awareness, healthcare access or cultural factors influencing health-seeking behaviour.

A significant methodological issue highlighted by this scoping review is the considerable variability in how the time from symptom recognition to initiation of treatment and its corresponding intervals were conceptualised and operationalised. This variability creates confusion, as identical terms are often used to refer to different intervals, leading to a lack of comparability. Despite the existence of validated tools and methods for assessing the timeliness of cancer care such as the Andersen model,78 the Model of Pathways to Treatment23 and the Aarhus Statement,79 only a small number of studies used these tools. The lack of standardised terms and metrics adds unnecessary complexity, jeopardising the potential value of the findings considering the diversity of social, economic and healthcare conditions across African countries. The WHO GBCI recommends clear time-bound benchmarks, achieving a diagnosis within 60 days of first presentation and initiating treatment within 30 days of diagnosis, to support timely and effective care. However, the limited uptake of standardised tools and metrics in African breast cancer research may hinder alignment with such global targets and impede efforts to improve outcomes.

Patients with breast cancer in many African countries often seek different initial points of contact on noticing their first symptoms. In several African countries, patients with breast cancer visit traditional healers or spiritual sites first after noticing early symptoms. These behaviours are likely to be influenced by cultural beliefs and misconceptions, including the perception that breast cancer is caused by supernatural forces, curses or ancestral punishment.51 80 Additionally, there is a widespread belief that cancer is fatal and incurable through conventional medical treatment, along with distrust in government healthcare systems and the social stigma associated with the disease.81 These cultural and traditional practices can result in many women presenting at health facilities with advanced stages of breast cancer, negatively affecting diagnosis and treatment outcomes.82 Indeed, three studies included in this current review identified visiting a traditional healer or spiritual places before contacting HCP as a significant predictor of longer time intervals in breast cancer journey. This is consistent with the findings of previous studies, where strong beliefs in traditional medicine and perhaps strong religious beliefs are deemed the main reasons for delays in presentation to HCP by patients with breast cancer in LMICs.76 80 83

There exist significant inequalities in breast cancer care in African countries. For example, older age,22 35 38 41 53 65 lower levels of education22 33 35 and rural residency22 36 52 are associated with longer time intervals. Additionally, the absence of a family history of breast cancer40 52 and not performing breast self-examination34 44 45 64 are also significant predictors of longer time intervals from symptom detection to initial healthcare contact and diagnosis.

The health system shortfalls and a lack of universal health coverage in African countries have contributed to the longer time intervals in breast cancer care. The lack of health insurance coverage,65 financial constraints39 and the need to travel long distances (over 100 km)29 present significant barriers for accessing breast cancer care. Poor infrastructure, workforce shortage and the absence of referral arrangements result in multiple paths for breast cancer care. Those who initially seek traditional therapy or visit multiple healthcare facilities are likely to experience additional longer time intervals in breast cancer diagnosis.36 42

This scoping review has revealed the importance of health literacy and patient empowerment for breast cancer care. In African countries, clinical characteristics like the absence of prior breast health issues, painless symptoms and no lump in the armpit are often linked to longer time intervals to HCP contact.22 52 Similarly, the absence of a palpable lump, fear of diagnosis,65 a history of fibrocystic disease,29 48 being married and long-term use of oral contraceptives35 38 were also identified as predictors of longer time intervals to diagnosis. Additionally, those diagnosed with late-stage cancer also experienced prolonged time intervals from diagnosis to treatment.41

This scoping review highlights several research gaps in breast cancer care in Africa. First, there is a scarcity of published data on treatment completion and follow-up due to most study designs ending with initiation of breast cancer treatment. This limits our understanding of loss to follow-up, which is a critical issue in resource-limited settings. This is a significant limitation, as loss to follow-up at any point in the care continuum may confound assessments of timeliness. Second, the existing studies primarily rely on hospital-based samples, which may not capture the full scope of the cancer burden in resource-limited settings where universal health coverage is lacking. A notable absence of community-based sampling limits the generalisability of findings as many patients may have never been diagnosed and treated in cancer care facilities. Moreover, patients who fail to complete the breast cancer care pathway, due to geographic, financial, sociocultural or health system barriers, are often excluded from analyses, which may limit the generalisability of findings to the broader population. Third, there is a paucity of qualitative studies exploring patients' experiences and barriers across the care pathway. Very few studies provide comprehensive insights into the entire journey, from initial symptom detection through to treatment initiation, encompassing all critical subintervals. Finally, there is a lack of locally developed, system-based criteria for assessing and defining the timeliness of breast cancer care.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This scoping review has several limitations. First, many studies in the review were cross-sectional and retrospective, relying on patient recall to estimate key events, such as the time symptoms were first noticed, which introduces the risk of recall bias. There is also the potential for social desirability bias, which may result in underestimating patient, diagnostic and treatment time intervals. Another limitation is that, as in most scoping reviews, no formal quality appraisal of the included studies was conducted, leaving the strength of the evidence uncertain. Despite a comprehensive literature search, some relevant studies may have been missed due to accessibility issues, and only English-language publications were included, potentially excluding literature in other languages. This scoping review also excluded those studies focused primarily on screening asymptomatic individuals. Finally, while the review covers the care pathway up to treatment initiation, it does not examine treatment completion.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The available evidence reveals significant variations both between and within African countries in how the timeliness of breast cancer care and time intervals are conceptualised and measured. These differences highlight the need for a greater use of validated, standardised tools to assess timeliness in a more consistent and comparable manner, which would better inform interventions aimed at reducing delays in breast cancer care. Further research, using common and standardise metrics, is needed to evaluate and improve timeliness of breast cancer care.

Breast cancer care in African countries is a long and complex journey, involving multiple care providers and paths, including decisions made by patients, their family members, traditional healers and religious providers, in addition to those of formal HCP.

This review also underscores the dual challenges relating to patient-mediated and health system-mediated factors for improving the breast cancer care journey in Africa. On the patient side, awareness campaigns tailored to cultural contexts and targeting older women and rural populations are crucial. On the system side, strengthening diagnostic infrastructure, improving referral pathways and addressing financial and geographic barriers are essential to ensure timely care. Addressing these interconnected challenges requires a multifaceted approach that integrates community education with systemic healthcare improvements to improve breast cancer outcomes and reduce related mortality across Africa. Engaging traditional and religious leaders in education and referrals to formal care should also be explored.

Future research should prioritise community-based sampling and qualitative studies to gain a more comprehensive understanding of breast cancer patterns and challenges. Additionally, studies focusing on treatment completion rates, follow-up care for breast cancer patients and the impact of failure to complete treatment are essential to address gaps in the care continuum and improve patient outcomes.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We are grateful to the La Trobe University Research Graduate Scholarship (LTURGS) for making available the necessary resources for completion of this study protocol.

fn.p: Funding: This review is funded by La Trobe University Research Graduate Scholarship (LTURGS). The funder didn’t influence the results/outcomes of the study despite author affiliations with the funder.
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-098087).

Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
